i just had to say this
summary: 1,) it’s not a sword, it’s literally described  as a knife. It’s perfectly reasonable for people in KL to have knives on them....
body:
Consider this my ultimate “Sansan debunk post”

1,) it’s not a sword, it’s literally described as a knife. It’s perfectly reasonable for people in KL to have knives on them. The show went with that explanation, sooo. Besides, you don’t think Sansa knows the difference?

He only was there to catch her arm because he snuck up on her like a creep.

2.) I have several posts explaining the UnKiss. TLDR: sign of trauma and her repressed memories, as confirmed by George himself. She only talks about it in negative, sexual assault terms. In the AFFC passage about it, directly before, she thinks about Loras fondly in constrast. “If I close my eyes I can pretend he is the Knight of Flowers”. Not the Hound, or Sandor. Loras. Her crush on Loras could be described as a more accurate cause of her “sexual awakening”, but she’s literally a child, and she isn’t “sexually awoken”, ya pervs.

3.) The associations with Tyrion- wedding kiss and wedding night- arent positive in the slightest. @fortunatelylori has a great post explaining Sansa’s nightmare, and if you search through my “anti Sansan”tag you’ll find many posts on this, and more. @lostlittlesatellites is the queen of Anti Sansan posts, as is @lady-in-a-song- her BATB series is excellent!

“Randomly thinking of him”because recurring intrusive thoughts aren’t a sign of trauma. Oh noooo… Because she’s an empathetic person, she tries to forgive him in her first ASOS chapter, but the book shows us the negative effects of his actions. She thinks of him as a protector when Marillion assaults her, then has a nightmare about his attempting to rape her.

Besides, ASOIAF isn’t all about trauma and it’s many diverse and negative effects AT ALL, that’s RIDICULOUS.

blog.name: hemavvls
blog.title: Don't know
blog.description: honestly here for fan art and edits

body:
YOU KNOW

I just want Sansa to outlive everyone one in the end…. And have her enemies perished…. Seriously like it gives me the ultimate satisfaction that a girl who everyone thought wouldn’t be able to survive (including her family) will most probably reign in the end…

Because let’s face it… It not going to be cercei because all the plot points suggest that she will most likely die out of her own destructions….

Also I love the thought of jonsa… But Jon Snow is pretty high up on the list of people who are most likely going to die

And Dany… As much as I love her arc… I don’t know I feel like her being the queen on Iron Throne is pretty much not going to be ending… You know what I mean…. Like it will refute everything the story is trying to say….

In conclusion…. Let’s be honest our girl Sansa Stark is least likely to die and I am thankful for that.

“Lady Stark. You may survive us yet”

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

title: SanSan ramblings
body:
I wanted to write on the parallels between Sansa/Littlefinger and Catherine Linton/Heathcliff. I had an inkling I wasn’t the first to catch on to those parallels. I checked. I was right 😭 too bad. There’s even a Wuthering Heights theory, apparently. 

Although! You know what set me thinking about those parallels? It wasn’t the Littlefinger = Heathcliff part (I’m embarrassed to admit how long it took me to see it, even though the story literally shoves it in our faces). It was this:

Sansa could hear the night wind moaning outside and scratching at the Moon Door.

This is soon after Lysa’s fall. Almost like it was Lysa’s ghost scratching at the Door, you know? And the ghost of Catherine Earnshaw (Heathcliff’s love gone wrong) is said to be scratching at the windows of Wuthering Heights… 

Mind you all, the “Wuthering Heights theory” concludes with Jon Snow as Catherine/Sansa’s Hareton. No doubt the j0nsa are all on board with this interpretation. For my part, I had another idea for Hareton. Someone more in line with his gruff manners, bluntness and unrefined speech. His name starts with an S. 

On a more serious note, though, I remember reading this Wuthering Heights analysis which put the “Earnshaw vs Linton” conflict as a metaphor for the clash between nature and society (and the character of Catherine Earnshaw as an embodiment of this conflict). I love how a similar theme is brought in Sansa’s storyline, with the North as the “nature/wilderness”, and the South as the “refined society”. Sansa, like Catherine Earnshaw, is torn between the two, although her heart obviously belongs to the North (yes, Sansa has a bit of Catherine Earnshaw in her as well. I think all the Stark girls do.)

summary: A Garden of Hopes and Dreams
title: A Garden of Hopes and Dreams
body:
Merry Christmas @strawberryhandkerchiefs 🎄🎁  I am your secret santa for @gotsecretsanta👋🏻 Here is your gift, it’s a SansaXMargaery fanfiction and I really hope you like it. I hope you have a wonderful week.

Sansa and Margaery had first come together one evening in a garden at King’s landing. A small rose garden that was tucked away from prying eyes and was watched by mainly Olenna’s spies. They had come together with flowers in their hair, caution in their touches and a hesitance to their words. It had all begun during those sparse moments when neither woman was being crushed under the cruel weight of the world. It had been an accident, but it had been perfect. 

Surprisingly, Sansa had been the one to act first.

She had spoken of her fears, of the dreams she had once had, of the hope that she would be saved. Margaery had listened, not saying a word, hardly even breathing. And, when she was finished Sansa had awaited with bated breath for Margaery to turn one her, to throw her to lions. Instead, Margaery had begun to speak as well. If Sansa’s words had escaped from her in a rush, Margaery’s were the exact opposite. She spoke in soft tones, her voice barely above a whisper and sometimes her silence explained more than her words. The two of them became each other’s confidence, the only piece of happiness that they each had claim to.

It had not taken long before those moments of spoken truth turned to soft touches, laughter and kisses. Sansa had always believed that she was in love, she had thought Joffery was her Prince, that Loras would be her knight in shining armour. Sansa had never been more wrong. The love that she felt for Margaery was unlike anything she had ever felt, it was tender, pure and ever so perfect. Loving Margaery was easier than breathing and at times she felt as if they were two halves of one soul.

Margaery had never been in love. She had flirted with the idea of it, but never had she dared even contemplate the idea until Sansa. For Margaery loving Sansa was terrifying. Margaery had always been in charge of her emotions, her grandmother had taught her from a young age how to control herself, how to become the perfect lady. But, Sansa made Margaery want to run away from her responsibilities. To travel the world, with nothing but the love they held for each other. The love that Margaery felt for Sansa was uncontrollable and consuming.  

But, the small haven they had built was torn apart. They had gone down different roads. Separated by fate. The Dragon Queen had come bringing fire and blood. The North had risen up, naming a King in the North and the dead rose from their slumber.

Yet, they had survived, they had survived it all.

The world now was so different from the one they had been born into, some of it was changed for the better, some for the worse. They had met once after the fall of the walkers for a mere hour and it was as if no time had passed at all. They had been hurried in their coupling. Margaery had worn high necked dresses for days due to the mark that Sansa has left on her neck and Sansa could feel the bruises that Margaery’s fingers had left behind on her thighs for weeks. They had agreed it wouldn’t happen again, that they were women grown and that their love had been that of two young girls, naïve to the ways of the world.

Oh, how wrong they were.

No matter what it seemed that they just kept coming back to each other. It was as if fate was apologising for all of the obstacles it had placed in their paths, for all the time it had kept them apart and the suffering they had endured. It was as if fate had decided to finally give them what they wanted.

Neither of them had married though there had been plenty of offers. They never spoke of their relationship but, Arya always looked at them knowingly and Willas seemed to constantly be encouraging Margaery to travel North.

                                                        XxX

If anyone were to ask Sansa’s opinion she would have told them it was funny how everything involving them always began in the garden. From the Watergardens of Dorne, to the Gardens of Gelenei in Braavos and Highgarden. Their love, seemed to blossom like the flowers that made the gardens their home. Though perhaps it was fitting that they would both be drawn to such places. Sansa had always loved flowers as a girl and it was no secret she adored them still as a woman grown. While Margaery was a Tyrell, the House of the golden rose sigil.

When she was younger Sansa had feared the Godswood, disliked it for the power that it held. Now, all she felt within it was love and safety. The Godswood of Winterfell seemed to chase away her fears, reminding her that she was home. The trees loomed above her creating a dense canopy of red and warm steam drifted up from the three small pools.

The pale blue dress she wore was rather light by Northern standards, lacking any fur and having a rather low neckline in comparison to the dresses she wore during the middle of Winter.

It was the complete opposite to Margaery’s dress. In fact, what Margaery was wearing could hardly be called a dress and Sansa had hardly been able to hold back her laughter when she had seen what her lover had chosen to wear. A white coat made of the fur from ice-bears was draped around the smaller woman’s frame, practically engulfing her. Currently Sansa could only see Margaery’s large brown eyes, the beautiful brunette having decided to wear a thick white fur cap. It was not at all in Northern fashion and Sansa wondered what it would take for her to persuade her lover into wearing a Northern style dress.

Neither of them said a word as Margaery walked up to Sansa, reaching for her hand. The two of them walked towards the hot springs, kneeling down and removing their shoes before dipping their feet into the warm water. Sansa couldn’t help giggling when Margaery nearly toppled over trying to bend down, the ever so graceful woman appearing more like a snowball than a Lady.

Over the years everything between them seemed to have a hidden meaning. They could tell how the other was feeling by the tone of voice they were using, if Margaery was being overly sweet than Sansa knew her lover was unhappy, tired and stressed. If Margaery reached out and entwined their pinkies together it meant that she needed strength, the strength to get through a memory, a nightmare that Sansa wished she could make disappear.

The two of them talked for hours, relishing the time they had together before removing their clothes and slipping into the water. Neither wanted to leave, both of them holding onto each other, imprinting every moment into their memory.  

When Margaery left a few days later Sansa would remember Margaery soft skin, the way that she gasped breathlessly when she came undone and the promises and sweet declarations of love.

Sansa would remember every moment of her time with Margaery and treasure it, protecting it until the moment when they could meet again.

Sansa didn’t pray anymore, not to any of the Gods for they had never answered her prayers. But, she did hope. Sansa hoped that the peace lasted, that the dragon Queen would keep her promises, that the North would stay strong and that those she loved would find happiness. Sansa had hoped for so many things when she was younger, but now she was careful not to hope for too many things. She made sure to hope for only the most important thing. She hoped that one day those fleeting touches and stolen kisses wouldn’t have to be hidden. That one day they wouldn’t have hide away in a garden. That one day she could just lie in the arms she felt safest in for an entire day without worry. Sansa hoped, she hoped that within in this new age she might finally be allowed keep her happiness.

                                                          XxX

The gardens had always been Margaery’s domain, it was where her secrets were made and her truths revealed.  The Godswood was no different for it was a garden and a Tyrell was always at home in a garden.

The wind was biting and she couldn’t stop herself from shivering, even though Sansa had been sure to assure that currently the North was experiencing what they called ‘summer’. Sometimes Margaery didn’t understand why Sansa loved her. Most people would have thought this was because Sansa was stunning, tall and voluptuous, with red hair that flowed down her back in a beautiful Northern braid. But, for Margaery her doubts had nothing to do with the beauty of her lover.

No, Margaery didn’t understand why Sansa, a pure, intelligent, kind hearted woman who had endured so much could bear to love her. Margaery had never apologised for who she was, for being cunning and self-preserving at times. The memory of Sansa in her arms had kept her alive, it had kept her from loosing all hope of a better world. Sansa was Margaery’s hope, her promise of a better future.

The time apart was painful, though they tried their best to stay together. They visited each other for months on end, taking diplomatic trips to Dorne or Braavos where they could change into common clothes and walk the streets hand in hand without fear.

But, sometimes when they were together it was more painful than being apart. Margaery had to restrain herself from wrapping her arm possessively around Sansa’s waist when a man attempted to court her. The memory of the soft, reverent touches that they shared and the way she stole Sansa’s breath replayed over and over in her head. Reminding her that what they shared did not need to be public, nor did it need the labels that their society wished to dictate to them. They loved each other.

In the Godswood she could hardly keep her hands to herself as she whispered sweet nothings into the shell of Sansa’s ear, kissing her lover until both of them had to pull away in need of air. Lover, Margaery loved that word, for Sansa was hers and she was Sansa’s.  

Margaery had always been the dreamer, with her head in the clouds and her heart on her sleeve. Her grandmother had taught her to guard her heart, but had never quite dragged Margaery into reality. Margaery had once dreamed of being a Queen, she had dreamed of playing the ‘game of thrones’. And though she had lost the ‘game of thrones’ in the end, admittedly she had played it better than most. Margaery had never dreamed of love, but now, it was all that she imagined when she closed her eyes. She dreamed of a better future, a place where everyone could find some form of happiness. Margaery dreamed of a better world filled with better people. But, if there was one thing that Margaery dreamed of the most it was Sansa, with her red hair, cornflower blue eyes and lips softer than the petal of any rose. She dreamed of a future where they could touch, speak and love as they both pleased, of a future where children who needed love and affection ran through a garden of roses and smiles were common place. Margaery dreamed.

In the Godswood she could hardly keep her hands to herself as she whispered sweet nothings into the shell of Sansa’s ear, kissing her lover until both of them had to pull away in need of air. Lover, Margaery loved that word, for Sansa was hers and she was Sansa’s.  

Margaery had always been the dreamer, with her head in the clouds and her heart on her sleeve. Her grandmother had taught her to guard her heart, but had never quite dragged Margaery into reality. Margaery had once dreamed of being a Queen, she had dreamed of playing the ‘game of thrones’. And though she had lost the ‘game of thrones’ in the end, admittedly she had played it better than most. Margaery had never dreamed of love, but now, it was all that she imagined when she closed her eyes. She dreamed of a better future, a place where everyone could find some form of happiness. Margaery dreamed of a better world filled with better people. But, if there was one thing that Margaery dreamed of the most it was Sansa, with her red hair, cornflower blue eyes and lips softer than the petal of any rose. She dreamed of a future where they could touch, speak and love as they both pleased, of a future where children who needed love and affection ran through a garden of roses and smiles were common place. Margaery dreamed.
trail.content:
Merry Christmas @strawberryhandkerchiefs 🎄🎁  I am your secret santa for @gotsecretsanta👋🏻 Here is your gift, it’s a SansaXMargaery fanfiction and I really hope you like it. I hope you have a wonderful week.

Sansa and Margaery had first come together one evening in a garden at King’s landing. A small rose garden that was tucked away from prying eyes and was watched by mainly Olenna’s spies. They had come together with flowers in their hair, caution in their touches and a hesitance to their words. It had all begun during those sparse moments when neither woman was being crushed under the cruel weight of the world. It had been an accident, but it had been perfect. 

Surprisingly, Sansa had been the one to act first.

She had spoken of her fears, of the dreams she had once had, of the hope that she would be saved. Margaery had listened, not saying a word, hardly even breathing. And, when she was finished Sansa had awaited with bated breath for Margaery to turn one her, to throw her to lions. Instead, Margaery had begun to speak as well. If Sansa’s words had escaped from her in a rush, Margaery’s were the exact opposite. She spoke in soft tones, her voice barely above a whisper and sometimes her silence explained more than her words. The two of them became each other’s confidence, the only piece of happiness that they each had claim to.

It had not taken long before those moments of spoken truth turned to soft touches, laughter and kisses. Sansa had always believed that she was in love, she had thought Joffery was her Prince, that Loras would be her knight in shining armour. Sansa had never been more wrong. The love that she felt for Margaery was unlike anything she had ever felt, it was tender, pure and ever so perfect. Loving Margaery was easier than breathing and at times she felt as if they were two halves of one soul.

Margaery had never been in love. She had flirted with the idea of it, but never had she dared even contemplate the idea until Sansa. For Margaery loving Sansa was terrifying. Margaery had always been in charge of her emotions, her grandmother had taught her from a young age how to control herself, how to become the perfect lady. But, Sansa made Margaery want to run away from her responsibilities. To travel the world, with nothing but the love they held for each other. The love that Margaery felt for Sansa was uncontrollable and consuming.  

But, the small haven they had built was torn apart. They had gone down different roads. Separated by fate. The Dragon Queen had come bringing fire and blood. The North had risen up, naming a King in the North and the dead rose from their slumber.

Yet, they had survived, they had survived it all.

The world now was so different from the one they had been born into, some of it was changed for the better, some for the worse. They had met once after the fall of the walkers for a mere hour and it was as if no time had passed at all. They had been hurried in their coupling. Margaery had worn high necked dresses for days due to the mark that Sansa has left on her neck and Sansa could feel the bruises that Margaery’s fingers had left behind on her thighs for weeks. They had agreed it wouldn’t happen again, that they were women grown and that their love had been that of two young girls, naïve to the ways of the world.

Oh, how wrong they were.

No matter what it seemed that they just kept coming back to each other. It was as if fate was apologising for all of the obstacles it had placed in their paths, for all the time it had kept them apart and the suffering they had endured. It was as if fate had decided to finally give them what they wanted.

Neither of them had married though there had been plenty of offers. They never spoke of their relationship but, Arya always looked at them knowingly and Willas seemed to constantly be encouraging Margaery to travel North.

                                                        XxX

If anyone were to ask Sansa’s opinion she would have told them it was funny how everything involving them always began in the garden. From the Watergardens of Dorne, to the Gardens of Gelenei in Braavos and Highgarden. Their love, seemed to blossom like the flowers that made the gardens their home. Though perhaps it was fitting that they would both be drawn to such places. Sansa had always loved flowers as a girl and it was no secret she adored them still as a woman grown. While Margaery was a Tyrell, the House of the golden rose sigil.

When she was younger Sansa had feared the Godswood, disliked it for the power that it held. Now, all she felt within it was love and safety. The Godswood of Winterfell seemed to chase away her fears, reminding her that she was home. The trees loomed above her creating a dense canopy of red and warm steam drifted up from the three small pools.

The pale blue dress she wore was rather light by Northern standards, lacking any fur and having a rather low neckline in comparison to the dresses she wore during the middle of Winter.

It was the complete opposite to Margaery’s dress. In fact, what Margaery was wearing could hardly be called a dress and Sansa had hardly been able to hold back her laughter when she had seen what her lover had chosen to wear. A white coat made of the fur from ice-bears was draped around the smaller woman’s frame, practically engulfing her. Currently Sansa could only see Margaery’s large brown eyes, the beautiful brunette having decided to wear a thick white fur cap. It was not at all in Northern fashion and Sansa wondered what it would take for her to persuade her lover into wearing a Northern style dress.

Neither of them said a word as Margaery walked up to Sansa, reaching for her hand. The two of them walked towards the hot springs, kneeling down and removing their shoes before dipping their feet into the warm water. Sansa couldn’t help giggling when Margaery nearly toppled over trying to bend down, the ever so graceful woman appearing more like a snowball than a Lady.

Over the years everything between them seemed to have a hidden meaning. They could tell how the other was feeling by the tone of voice they were using, if Margaery was being overly sweet than Sansa knew her lover was unhappy, tired and stressed. If Margaery reached out and entwined their pinkies together it meant that she needed strength, the strength to get through a memory, a nightmare that Sansa wished she could make disappear.

The two of them talked for hours, relishing the time they had together before removing their clothes and slipping into the water. Neither wanted to leave, both of them holding onto each other, imprinting every moment into their memory.  

When Margaery left a few days later Sansa would remember Margaery soft skin, the way that she gasped breathlessly when she came undone and the promises and sweet declarations of love.

Sansa would remember every moment of her time with Margaery and treasure it, protecting it until the moment when they could meet again.

Sansa didn’t pray anymore, not to any of the Gods for they had never answered her prayers. But, she did hope. Sansa hoped that the peace lasted, that the dragon Queen would keep her promises, that the North would stay strong and that those she loved would find happiness. Sansa had hoped for so many things when she was younger, but now she was careful not to hope for too many things. She made sure to hope for only the most important thing. She hoped that one day those fleeting touches and stolen kisses wouldn’t have to be hidden. That one day they wouldn’t have hide away in a garden. That one day she could just lie in the arms she felt safest in for an entire day without worry. Sansa hoped, she hoped that within in this new age she might finally be allowed keep her happiness.

                                                          XxX

The gardens had always been Margaery’s domain, it was where her secrets were made and her truths revealed.  The Godswood was no different for it was a garden and a Tyrell was always at home in a garden.

The wind was biting and she couldn’t stop herself from shivering, even though Sansa had been sure to assure that currently the North was experiencing what they called ‘summer’. Sometimes Margaery didn’t understand why Sansa loved her. Most people would have thought this was because Sansa was stunning, tall and voluptuous, with red hair that flowed down her back in a beautiful Northern braid. But, for Margaery her doubts had nothing to do with the beauty of her lover.

No, Margaery didn’t understand why Sansa, a pure, intelligent, kind hearted woman who had endured so much could bear to love her. Margaery had never apologised for who she was, for being cunning and self-preserving at times. The memory of Sansa in her arms had kept her alive, it had kept her from loosing all hope of a better world. Sansa was Margaery’s hope, her promise of a better future.

The time apart was painful, though they tried their best to stay together. They visited each other for months on end, taking diplomatic trips to Dorne or Braavos where they could change into common clothes and walk the streets hand in hand without fear.

But, sometimes when they were together it was more painful than being apart. Margaery had to restrain herself from wrapping her arm possessively around Sansa’s waist when a man attempted to court her. The memory of the soft, reverent touches that they shared and the way she stole Sansa’s breath replayed over and over in her head. Reminding her that what they shared did not need to be public, nor did it need the labels that their society wished to dictate to them. They loved each other.

In the Godswood she could hardly keep her hands to herself as she whispered sweet nothings into the shell of Sansa’s ear, kissing her lover until both of them had to pull away in need of air. Lover, Margaery loved that word, for Sansa was hers and she was Sansa’s.  

Margaery had always been the dreamer, with her head in the clouds and her heart on her sleeve. Her grandmother had taught her to guard her heart, but had never quite dragged Margaery into reality. Margaery had once dreamed of being a Queen, she had dreamed of playing the ‘game of thrones’. And though she had lost the ‘game of thrones’ in the end, admittedly she had played it better than most. Margaery had never dreamed of love, but now, it was all that she imagined when she closed her eyes. She dreamed of a better future, a place where everyone could find some form of happiness. Margaery dreamed of a better world filled with better people. But, if there was one thing that Margaery dreamed of the most it was Sansa, with her red hair, cornflower blue eyes and lips softer than the petal of any rose. She dreamed of a future where they could touch, speak and love as they both pleased, of a future where children who needed love and affection ran through a garden of roses and smiles were common place. Margaery dreamed.

This one will be put in the category “Dark Smut.” Not in the bondage sense, but in the dark, forbidden love kind of sense. Consider yourself warned – less a “lovey” one than other stories I’ve written. But totally PWP.

I have to give a shout-out to blodeuweddbach and their work “Terms of Surrender.” I loved this idea that I had to take my own twist on it.
